page.title: 11ETHERLEY - HISTORY - 1
page.content: Etherley used to be a Pit Village. The last colliery closed in 1968. Sixty years ago, mining was a natural choice of job for a 14 year old and a walk to Hamsterly was the usual way to get to work. Pay was 6 pence a day for a six day working week. After 1926 unemployment rose and most left school at 14 to join the dole at 37.5 pence a week. In 1947 an explosion in the mine at West Auckland brought home the dangers of working underground. Two men were killed and five burnt. Havelock Holmes, a 76 year old local resident says that times have changed in Etherley. Beer used to be 3 pence a pint but women were 'looked down on' if they drank in public.
